articles.title: Tiny magnetic spirals unlock the future of spintronics
articles.summary: Scientists in Korea have engineered magnetic nanohelices that can control electron spin with extraordinary precision at room temperature. By combining structural chirality and magnetism, these nanoscale helices can filter spins without complex circuitry or cooling. The breakthrough not only demonstrates a way to program handedness in inorganic nanomaterials but also opens the door to scalable, energy-efficient spintronic devices that could revolutionize computing.
articles.content:
Spintronics, or spin-electronics, is a revolutionary approach to information processing that utilizes the intrinsic angular momentum (spin) of electrons, rather than solely relying on electric charge flow. This technology promises faster, more energy-efficient data storage and logic devices. A central challenge in fully realizing spintronics has been the development of materials that can precisely control electron spin direction.

In a groundbreaking development for spin-nanotechnology, researchers led by Professor Young Keun Kim of Korea University and Professor Ki Tae Nam of Seoul National University have successfully created magnetic nanohelices that can control electron spin. This technology, which utilizes chiral magnetic materials to regulate electron spin at room temperature, has been published in Science.

"These nanohelices achieve spin polarization exceeding ~80% -- just by their geometry and magnetism," stated Professor Young Keun Kim of Korea University, a co-corresponding author of the study. He further emphasized, "This is a rare combination of structural chirality and intrinsic ferromagnetism, enabling spin filtering at room temperature without complex magnetic circuitry or cryogenics, and provides a new way to engineer electron behavior using structural design."

The research team successfully fabricated left- and right-handed chiral magnetic nanohelices by electrochemically controlling the metal crystallization process. A critical innovation involved introducing trace amounts of chiral organic molecules, such as cinchonine or cinchonidine, which guided the formation of helices with precisely defined handedness -- a feat rarely achieved in inorganic systems. Also, the team experimentally demonstrated that when these nanohelices exhibit a right-handedness, they preferentially allow one direction of spin to pass, while the opposite spin cannot. The above marks the discovery of a 3D inorganic helical nanostructure capable of electron spin control.

"Chirality is well-understood in organic molecules, where the handedness of a structure often determines its biological or chemical function," noted Professor Ki Tae Nam of Seoul National University, also a co-corresponding author. "But in metals and inorganic materials, controlling chirality during synthesis is extremely difficult, especially at the nanoscale. The fact that we could program the direction of inorganic helices simply by adding chiral molecules is a breakthrough in materials chemistry."

To confirm the chirality of nanohelices, the researchers developed an electromotive force (emf)-based chirality evaluation method and measured the emf generated by the helices under rotating magnetic fields. The left- and right-handed helices produced opposite emf signals, allowing for quantitative verification of chirality even in materials that do not strongly interact with light.

The research team also found that the magnetic material itself, through its inherent magnetization (spin alignment), enables long-distance spin transport at room temperature. This effect, maintained by strong exchange energy, is constant regardless of the angle between the chiral axis and the spin injection direction, and was not observed in non-magnetic nanohelices of the same scale. The above marks the first measurement of asymmetric spin transport in a relatively macro-scaled chiral body. The team also demonstrated a solid-state device that showed chirality-dependent conduction signals, paving the way for practical spintronic applications.

Professor Kim highlighted the potential impact: "We believe this system could become a platform for chiral spintronics and architecture of chiral magnetic nanostructures." This work represents a powerful convergence of geometry, magnetism, and spin transport, built from scalable, inorganic materials. The ability to control the handedness (left/right) and even the number of strands (double, multiple helices) using this versatile electrochemical method is expected to contribute significantly to new application areas.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in spintronics technology with broad implications for faster, more energy-efficient computing. The development of magnetic nanohelices that control electron spin at room temperature without complex circuitry or cooling represents a major advance with potential large-scale societal impact in information processing and device engineering. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a novel, scalable method with clear real-world benefits.
articles.personality_title: Scientists create tiny magnetic spirals to control electron spins at room temperature
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Spintronics is a new technology that uses the spin of electrons to store and process information. It promises faster and more energy-efficient devices but needs materials that can control electron spins precisely.

**What happened** – Researchers in South Korea built tiny magnetic spirals called nanohelices that can control electron spins at room temperature. These spirals have a special shape called chirality, meaning they twist either left or right. By adding small amounts of chiral molecules during their creation, the team made spirals with a specific twist direction. These nanohelices can filter electron spins without needing complicated circuits or cooling systems.

**Impact** – This is the first time scientists have made inorganic materials with a controlled twist that can manage electron spin so well at normal temperatures. The spirals can pass electrons spinning one way while blocking the opposite spin. This discovery could lead to new, energy-saving electronic devices that work faster and use less power.

**What's next step** – The researchers plan to build more complex nanohelices with multiple twists and improve their designs. They hope to create practical spintronic devices that can be used in computers and other electronics, making them smaller and more efficient.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Korean scientists have made tiny magnetic spirals that control electron spins at room temperature, opening doors to better, energy-saving electronics.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des spirales magnétiques minuscules contrôlent les spins électroniques à température ambiante
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La spintronique est une nouvelle technologie qui utilise le spin des électrons pour stocker et traiter l'information. Elle promet des appareils plus rapides et économes en énergie, mais nécessite des matériaux capables de contrôler précisément les spins des électrons.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs sud-coréens ont fabriqué de minuscules spirales magnétiques appelées nanohélices capables de contrôler les spins électroniques à température ambiante. Ces spirales ont une forme spéciale appelée chiralité, ce qui signifie qu'elles tournent vers la gauche ou vers la droite. En ajoutant de petites quantités de molécules chirales pendant leur fabrication, l'équipe a créé des spirales avec un sens de torsion précis. Ces nanohélices peuvent filtrer les spins électroniques sans circuits complexes ni refroidissement.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que des matériaux inorganiques avec une torsion contrôlée peuvent gérer les spins électroniques aussi bien à température normale. Les spirales laissent passer les électrons tournant dans un sens tout en bloquant ceux dans l’autre. Cette découverte pourrait conduire à des dispositifs électroniques nouveaux, économes en énergie, plus rapides et plus petits.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs veulent fabriquer des nanohélices plus complexes avec plusieurs torsions et améliorer leurs conceptions. Ils espèrent créer des dispositifs spintroniques pratiques pour les ordinateurs et autres appareils électroniques, les rendant plus petits et plus efficaces.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Des scientifiques coréens ont créé de minuscules spirales magnétiques contrôlant les spins électroniques à température ambiante, ouvrant la voie à des appareils électroniques meilleurs et plus économes en énergie.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos crean diminutas espirales magnéticas para controlar los espines electrónicos a temperatura ambiente
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La espintrónica es una tecnología nueva que usa el espín de los electrones para almacenar y procesar información. Promete dispositivos más rápidos y con menos consumo de energía, pero necesita materiales que controlen con precisión los espines electrónicos.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de Corea del Sur fabricaron diminutas espirales magnéticas llamadas nanohélices que pueden controlar los espines electrónicos a temperatura ambiente. Estas espirales tienen una forma especial llamada quiralidad, que significa que giran hacia la izquierda o hacia la derecha. Añadiendo pequeñas cantidades de moléculas quirales durante su fabricación, el equipo creó espirales con un giro definido. Estas nanohélices pueden filtrar los espines electrónicos sin circuitos complicados ni enfriamiento.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que se fabrican materiales inorgánicos con un giro controlado que manejan tan bien los espines a temperatura normal. Las espirales permiten pasar electrones con un espín y bloquean los que tienen el espín opuesto. Este avance podría llevar a dispositivos electrónicos nuevos, que ahorran energía, son más rápidos y pequeños.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores planean crear nanohélices más complejas con múltiples giros y mejorar sus diseños. Esperan construir dispositivos espintrónicos prácticos para computadoras y otros aparatos, haciéndolos más pequeños y eficientes.

**Frase clave** – Científicos coreanos crearon diminutas espirales magnéticas que controlan los espines electrónicos a temperatura ambiente, abriendo el camino a dispositivos electrónicos mejores y que ahorran energía.

articles.title: Physicists just found a way to make “something from nothing”
articles.summary: Researchers at UBC have found a way to mimic the elusive Schwinger effect using superfluid helium, where vortex pairs appear out of thin films instead of electron-positron pairs in a vacuum. Their work not only offers a cosmic laboratory for otherwise unreachable phenomena, but also changes the way scientists understand vortices, superfluids, and even quantum tunneling.
articles.content:
In 1951, physicist Julian Schwinger theorized that by applying a uniform electrical field to a vacuum, electron-positron pairs would be spontaneously created out of nothing, through a phenomenon called quantum tunneling.

The problem with turning the matter-out-of-nowhere theory into Star Trek replicators or transporters? Enormously high electric fields would be required -- far beyond the limits of any direct physical experiments.

As a result, the aptly named Schwinger effect has never been seen.

Now theoretical physicists at the University of British Columbia (UBC) have described a parallel effect in a more manageable system. In their model, they substitute a thin film of superfluid helium for the vacuum, and the background flow of the superfluid for the massive electrical field.

"Superfluid Helium-4 is a wonder. At a few atomic layers thick it can be cooled very easily to a temperature where it's basically in a frictionless vacuum state," explains Dr. Philip Stamp, a theorist at UBC working on condensed matter and quantum gravity, and author of the new findings published on Sept. 2 in PNAS.

"When we make that frictionless vacuum flow, instead of electron-positron pairs appearing, vortex/anti-vortex pairs will appear spontaneously, spinning in opposite directions to one another."

In the paper, Dr. Stamp and UBC colleague Michael Desrochers outline the theory and the mathematics behind it -- mapping out a detailed approach to conducting a direct experiment.

Vacuum tunneling is a process of keen interest in quantum mechanics and quantum field theory. In quantum theory, vacuums aren't empty, they're filled with fluctuating fields that can lead to the temporary appearance and disappearance of virtual particles.

"We believe the Helium-4 film provides a nice analog to several cosmic phenomena," adds Dr. Stamp. "The vacuum in deep space, quantum black holes, even the very beginning of the Universe itself. And these are phenomena we can't ever approach in any direct experimental way."

However, Dr. Stamp emphasizes that the real interest of the work may lie less in an analogs - which always have limitations - and more in the way it alters our understanding of superfluids, and of phase transitions in two-dimensional systems.

"These are real physical systems in their own right, not analogs. And we can do experiments on these."

At the mathematical level, the researchers needed several breakthroughs to make the theory work. For example, previous researchers looking at vortices in superfluids have treated the vortex mass as an unchanging constant. Dr. Stamp and Desrochers showed that this mass will vary dramatically as the vortices move, fundamentally changing our understanding of vortices in both fluids and the early universe.

"It's exciting to understand how and why the mass varies, and how this affects our understanding of quantum tunneling processes, which are ubiquitous in physics, chemistry and biology," says Desrochers.

Stamp also argues that the same mass variability will occur with electron-positron pairs in the Schwinger effect, thence modifying Schwinger's theory, in a kind of 'revenge of the analog'.

The work was supported by the National Science and Engineering Research Council.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant theoretical breakthrough in physics where researchers have found a practical analog to the elusive Schwinger effect, enabling experimental study of quantum tunneling phenomena previously unreachable. This advances fundamental scientific understanding with broad implications for quantum mechanics, cosmology, and condensed matter physics.
articles.personality_title: Physicists recreate ‘something from nothing’ effect using superfluid helium
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 1951, physicist Julian Schwinger predicted that a strong electric field could create pairs of particles, electrons and positrons, out of empty space. This strange idea, called the Schwinger effect, has never been seen because it needs extremely powerful electric fields that are impossible to create in experiments.

**What happened** – Researchers at the University of British Columbia (UBC) found a way to copy the Schwinger effect using superfluid helium instead of empty space. Superfluid helium is a special liquid that flows without friction when cooled to very low temperatures. They showed that when they make this superfluid flow, tiny whirlpools called vortex pairs suddenly appear, spinning in opposite directions, similar to the particle pairs in the original effect. They explained the math behind this and how to test it in experiments.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because it lets scientists study a complex quantum process in a lab instead of just imagining it in space. It also changes how we think about vortices in superfluids and how their mass changes as they move. This new understanding could affect many areas of science, including how particles behave in the early universe and inside black holes.

**What’s next step** – The UBC team plans to carry out experiments to observe these vortex pairs directly. Their work might also lead to new discoveries about quantum tunneling, the process that allows particles to appear and disappear, which is important in physics, chemistry, and biology.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists have created a lab version of a famous quantum effect, opening new ways to study how particles can appear from empty space using flowing superfluid helium.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des physiciens recréent l’effet « quelque chose à partir de rien » avec de l’hélium superfluide
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 1951, le physicien Julian Schwinger a prédit qu’un champ électrique très fort pouvait créer des paires de particules, électrons et positrons, à partir du vide. Cet effet étrange, appelé effet Schwinger, n’a jamais été observé car il nécessite des champs électriques bien trop puissants pour être reproduits en laboratoire.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université de la Colombie-Britannique (UBC) ont trouvé un moyen de reproduire cet effet en utilisant de l’hélium superfluide à la place du vide. L’hélium superfluide est un liquide spécial qui s’écoule sans frottement à très basse température. Ils ont montré qu’en faisant couler ce superfluide, de petites tourbillons appelés paires de vortex apparaissent soudainement, tournant en sens opposé, comme les paires de particules dans l’effet original. Ils ont expliqué la théorie mathématique et comment le tester en laboratoire.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle permet d’étudier un phénomène quantique complexe en laboratoire, au lieu de seulement l’imaginer dans l’espace. Elle change aussi notre compréhension des vortex dans les superfluides et de la façon dont leur masse varie en bougeant. Cela pourrait influencer plusieurs domaines scientifiques, comme le comportement des particules dans l’univers primordial ou à l’intérieur des trous noirs.

**Prochaine étape** – L’équipe de l’UBC prévoit de réaliser des expériences pour observer directement ces paires de vortex. Leur travail pourrait aussi mener à de nouvelles découvertes sur le phénomène de tunneling quantique, qui permet aux particules d’apparaître et de disparaître, important en physique, chimie et biologie.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Des scientifiques ont créé une version en laboratoire d’un célèbre effet quantique, ouvrant de nouvelles voies pour étudier comment des particules peuvent apparaître à partir du vide grâce à l’écoulement d’hélium superfluide.
articles.personality_title_es: Físicos recrean el efecto de ‘algo de la nada’ usando helio superfluido
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 1951, el físico Julian Schwinger predijo que un campo eléctrico muy fuerte podría crear pares de partículas, electrones y positrones, a partir del vacío. Este extraño efecto, llamado efecto Schwinger, nunca se ha visto porque requiere campos eléctricos demasiado poderosos para hacerlos en experimentos.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de British Columbia (UBC) encontraron una forma de imitar el efecto Schwinger usando helio superfluido en lugar de vacío. El helio superfluido es un líquido especial que fluye sin fricción a temperaturas muy bajas. Mostraron que al hacer fluir este superfluido, aparecen de repente pequeños remolinos llamados pares de vórtices, que giran en direcciones opuestas, parecido a las parejas de partículas del efecto original. Explicaron la teoría matemática y cómo probarlo en experimentos.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es importante porque permite a los científicos estudiar un proceso cuántico complejo en el laboratorio en vez de solo imaginarlo en el espacio. También cambia cómo entendemos los vórtices en superfluidos y cómo su masa cambia al moverse. Esto podría afectar muchas áreas de la ciencia, como el comportamiento de partículas en el universo temprano y dentro de los agujeros negros.

**Próximo paso** – El equipo de UBC planea realizar experimentos para observar directamente estos pares de vórtices. Su trabajo podría llevar a nuevos descubrimientos sobre el tunelamiento cuántico, el proceso que permite que las partículas aparezcan y desaparezcan, importante en física, química y biología.

**Resumen en una frase** – Científicos han creado una versión en laboratorio de un famoso efecto cuántico, abriendo nuevas formas de estudiar cómo las partículas pueden aparecer del vacío usando helio superfluido en movimiento.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of a thin, translucent film of superfluid helium flowing gently like a shimmering river, with pairs of glowing, swirling vortex and anti-vortex spirals spontaneously emerging and spinning in opposite directions above the surface, set against a soft, abstract cosmic background evoking deep space and quantum fields.
